instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.SYS_DETECT_L: What is SYS_DETECT_L? For detection of the battery.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message:
Water damaged around battery connector.

Already changed <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> due to lower resistance on <SIGNAL>CHGR_UGATE</SIGNAL>. (0.110 vs 0.527 on known good?). It measured around 0.527 after replace. Laptop started, battery not recognized yet.

Checked <SIGNAL>CHGR_UGATE</SIGNAL> and it's around 0.110 now.

ISL pins 17/18 (3.9 Ohms) pins 27/28 (20.5 Ohms)

<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL> - 0.469
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL> - 0.470
<SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_L</SIGNAL> - 1.699

PPBUS with battery - 0V.
PPBUS without battery - 12.59V.

Did battery just kill two ISL chips?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message: Bad battery it sounds like. If it doesn't see the battery, but you get 12.59 volts on PPBUS without the battery, highly likely a bad battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message: Forgot to say that it was water damaged with some liquid to be seen around battery connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message:
Liquid spill under J7050 can easy kill the SMC through SCL line; closesest to power pins.
But you have correct resistance to ground (diode mode) at both SCL/SDA lines.
Confirm if valid for voltage too.

Don't waste time measuring around <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> if you get correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> without battery.

When only battery connected (no charger), post voltage on battery connector and F7140.
Be sure <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> is not shorted.

I recommend you to try a known good battery; even old, just for test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>:
pins 123 (0.113) pin 4 (0.620) pin 5 (OL)

Plugged in old "dead" battery from 2014.

PPBUS was 12.87V when laptop started. Now while in OSX it's 12.57V.
SDA and SCL give 3.42V.
J7050 pins 10, 11, 12 give 2.23V with old battery plugged in.

I'm connected to DPCS now (drawing 270mA) and battery status says: Replace now, Battery is not charging.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message:
That message means the battery is recognized.
Confirm that in System Report...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message:
Confirmed. Battery is recognized. 

Is there anything that could be done on battery side board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message: Special software and interface required; just change the battery...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message:
Will do so. Thank you. 

Last question for this thread: any good sources to get original battery or at least high quality battery in Europe? Or this battery game is just blind roulette?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message: Apple store has higher price. I was thinking more of buying and installing it myself.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message: New battery out of Apple store, imagine the quality you'll get...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message: Well I guess it?s Apple store then. Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message:
You can try to get second hand one, instead of new chinese garbage.
But look at cycles count before you pay for it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't see nor charge battery
threads.message: They appear like unicorns on eBay etc., but that?s an option too, yes.
